verses.verse: ((1 Job moved by the importunacy of his friends,7 Counteth in what extremity he is.19 And taketh God to witness of his innocence.) ) But Job answered and said,
I have oftentimes heard such things: miserable comforters are ye all.
Shall there be none end of words of (Which serve for vain ostentation and for no true comfort.) wind? or what maketh thee bold so to (For Eliphaz did reply against Job’s answer.) answer?

I could also speak as ye do: (but would God your (I would you felt that which I do.) soul were in my soul’s stead) I could keep you company in speaking, and could (That is, mock at your misery, as you do at mine.) shake mine head at you,
But I would strengthen you (If this were in my power, yet would I comfort you, and not do as ye do to me.) with my mouth, and the comfort of my lips should assuage your sorrow.

Though I speak, my sorrow (If they would say, Why dost thou not then comfort thyself? he answereth, that the judgments of God are more heavy than he is able to assuage either by words or silence.) cannot be assuaged: though I cease, what release have I?
But now (Meaning, God.) he maketh me weary: O God, thou hast made all my (That is, destroyed most of my family.) congregation desolate,
And hast made me full of (In token of sorrow and grief.) wrinkles which is a witness thereof, and my leanness riseth up in me, testifying the same in my face.

(That is, God by his wrath: and in this diversity of words and high style, he expresseth how grievous the hand of God was upon him.) His wrath hath torn me, and he hateth me, and gnasheth upon me with his teeth: mine enemy hath sharpened his eyes against me.

They have opened their mouths upon me, and smitten me on the (That is, hath handled me most contemptuously: for so smiting on the cheek signified, 1 Kings 22:24; Mark 14:65.) cheek in reproach: they gathered themselves together against me.
God hath delivered me to the unjust, and hath made me to turn out of the way by the (They have led me whither they would.) hands of the wicked.
I was in wealth, but he hath brought me to nought: he hath taken me by the neck and beaten me, and set me as a mark for himself.
His (His manifold afflictions.) archers compass me round about: he cutteth my reins, and doth not spare, and poureth my gall (I am wounded to the heart.) upon the ground.
He hath broken me with one breaking upon another, and runneth upon me like a giant.
I have sowed a sackcloth upon my skin, and have abased mine (Meaning, his glory was brought low.) horn unto the dust.
My face is withered with weeping, and the shadow of death is upon mine eyes,

Though there be no wickedness in (Signifying, that he is not able to comprehend the cause of this his grievous punishment.) mine hands, and my prayer (That is, unfeigned, and without hypocrisy.) be pure.
O earth, cover not thou my (Let my sin be known if I be such a sinner as mine adversaries accuse me, and let me find no favor.) blood, and let my crying find no place.
For lo, now my (Though man condemn me, yet God is witness of my cause.) witness is in the heaven, and my record is on high.
My friends (Use painted words instead of true consolation.) speak eloquently against me: but mine eye poureth out tears unto God.

Oh that a man might (Thus by his great torments he is carried away, and breaketh out into passions, and speaketh unadvisedly, as though God should entreat man more gently, seeing he hath but a short time here to live.) plead with God, as man with his neighbor!
For the years accounted come, and I shall go the way, whence I shall not return.
